title: China's Manufacturing Sector Shows Signs of Strength
summary: Beijing attributes pickup to a drop in commodity prices after governmental intervention to stabilize supply and prices. BEIJING-China's manufacturing and service sectors showed unexpected signs of recovery to close out the year, according to a pair of official gauges released Friday, as Beijing moved to arrest a downward spiral triggered by a real-estate slump and coronavirus outbreaks.

title: Colorado Fire Burns Hundreds of Homes, Businesses
summary: Thousands in Louisville and Superior told to leave, as high winds fan flames. Hundreds of homes and businesses in Boulder County, Colo., burned Thursday as strong winds fanned a fast-moving wildfire into heavily populated suburban areas

title: Biden, Putin Warn of Danger to Relations if Ukraine Crisis Escalates
summary: Moscow has built up troops near Ukraine and issued demands to NATO and the U.S.. President Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin warned each other of the potential for a dangerous downturn in relations if the current crisis over Ukraine further escalates, but kept a pathway open for diplomacy.

title: Truck Driver's 110-Year Prison Term Is Cut to 10 Years
summary: The 110-year sentence imposed on Rogel Aguilera-Mederos for a deadly 2019 highway crash in Colorado drew outrage earlier this month. A truck driver who received a 110-year prison term for a Colorado highway crash that killed four people has had his sentence reduced sharply by the state's governor.

title: Airlines Cancel More Than 1,300 Flights
summary: The FAA says its air-traffic control staffing may also come under pressure. The coronavirus surge continued to disrupt U.S. air travel as airlines canceled hundreds of flights Thursday, while the Federal Aviation Administration warned of possible delays because of the agency's own Covid-related staffing challenges.

title: 10 Things to Love About America
summary: An immigrant's social media posts express love for the land to which he came.. Amjad Masad came to America in January 2012. He was from Amman, Jordan, and 24. He came because his father, a Palestinian immigrant to Jordan and a government worker, bought him a computer when he was 6. Amjad fell in love and discovered his true language. He studied the history of the computer and became enamored of the U.S. and Silicon Valley. He imagined the latter as a futuristic place with flying cars and floating buildings. He saw the 1999 movie "Pirates of Silicon Valley," about Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, and decided America was the place he must be.

title: California Is Making Bacon More Expensive
summary: A new law will force pork producers nationwide to comply with onerous regulations.. Meat prices have been surging. The cost of pork is up 17% over the past year. A California ballot initiative, set to take effect on Saturday, may send ham and bacon prices up even more.

title: The Conformity Crackup of 2021
summary: From Covid lockdowns to crime and cops, the political-media consensus was wrong.. The year 2021 that ends this week wasn't the return to normalcy that President Biden promised, but it was invaluable in one respect. This was the year when the conformity that characterizes American politics and media was exposed for its mistakes as never before.

title: The T-Cell Covid Cavalry
summary: Two studies suggest this line of defense reduces Omicron's severity.. We hope this isn't forbidden to report by the public-health pessimists, but there's some good news about the vaccine defense against the Omicron variant. A pair of separate studies-from the Netherlands and South Africa-have found that T cells mobilized by vaccination reduce the severity of the disease.

title: Hallelujah, a New Mayor for New York
summary: Bill de Blasio leaves Eric Adams a mess, but he can't do any worse than eight years of progressive failure.. New Yorkers have special reason to celebrate this New Year's Eve, which is the last day of Mayor Bill de Blasio's eight years of progressive failure. Everything in the city is worse than Mr. de Blasio found it, which means new Mayor Eric Adams inherits a mess but also has a turnaround opportunity.

title: The Chicago Teachers Union's Priorities
summary: Will the union let public schools reopen after the holidays?. Chicago's public schools will reopen Monday after the Christmas and New Year's break. That's the welcome word from Pedro Martinez, the Chicago Public Schools CEO. Alas, the Chicago Teachers Union may decide otherwise.

title: When the Hammer (and Sickle) Fell
summary: Thirty years ago, the New Year's midnight bells also ushered out the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.. At midnight on Dec. 31, 1991, the chimes rang out from Savior Tower in the Kremlin and fireworks lit up the sky, marking the final end of the Soviet Union, which claimed to have created heaven on earth.

title: No Facebook Funding for Elections
summary: Mark Zuckerberg donated $400 million to districts that mostly elect Democrats.. What's a good way to erode Americans' trust in elections further? The answer can be found in North Carolina, where Gov. Roy Cooper recently vetoed a bill that would ban private funding for public election administration. Such funding was rampant in 2020-in North Carolina and nationwide-and it likely benefited Democrats. Some states have already enacted a ban, and more should follow before the 2022 midterms.

title: So You Want to Run for the Senate?
summary: Good luck. Here are some questions you should ask yourself.. Glenn Youngkin's surprise gubernatorial win in Virginia has other wealthy Wall Streeters thinking they could run and win too-and the Republican Party is egging them on, remembering the $20 million of personal money Mr. Youngkin threw into his campaign.

title: How Presidents Ring In the New Year
summary: Jimmy Carter toasted the shah. Donald Trump tweeted.. How you celebrate New Year's Eve can reveal a lot. Extroverts revel in party and song. Homebodies remain home as balls drop and corks pop. When it comes to presidents, their Dec. 31 habits have often reflected their character and that of their presidencies.

title: Galileo and the Pandemic
summary: His lockdown in Florence complicated his relationship with the church's censors.. I was completing a doctorate in the history of science and technology at Johns Hopkins University in March 2020, when the pandemic upended my professional life as it has countless others. The university administration sent an email announcing the closing of campus and encouraging researchers "to focus on the activities that can be completed remotely, such as writing papers and grant proposals, and completing data analysis."

title: 'Champagne Charlie' Review: The Trouble With Bubbles
summary: Antebellum Americans had a rough introduction to Champagne. Some drank it sweetened with sugar or syrup. One label was made from rhubarb.. There is a photograph, dated 1911, of the explorer Robert Falcon Scott and his team. En route to the South Pole, the men are seated around a table, looking rather the worse for wear after a celebratory midwinter meal of seal soup, roast beef, plum pudding, minced pies and an "unstinted" supply of Champagne Charles Heidsieck. Had the Champagne label's founder still been alive, he would have been thrilled to see that his brand had made it to Antarctica.

title: U.S. Hits Record Number of New Covid Cases Twice in Same Week
summary: Omicron surge continues as governments around the world ease self-isolation rules. New daily Covid-19 cases in the U.S. set a fresh record on Wednesday, as the World Health Organization warned governments that easing self-isolation rules and testing requirements come with a trade-off between slowing transmission rates and keeping economies running.

title: Stocks Finish Modestly Lower
summary: Figures show that weekly first-time applications for unemployment benefits, a proxy for layoffs, stayed near decade lows. U.S. stocks finished slightly lower Thursday, reversing intraday gains after fresh economic data indicated a recent uptick in Covid-19 infections related to the Omicron variant hasn't led to a surge in layoffs.

title: Tesla Recalls Vehicles Over Camera, Front Hood Faults
summary: The recalls apply to hundreds of thousands of cars from recent model years. Tesla Inc. is recalling nearly half a million cars it has produced in recent years because of potential safety defects, federal regulators said, adding to previous recalls and other safety concerns that have hit the electric-vehicle maker this year.

title: A Year to Watch (Friday Crossword, December 31)
'Around the World in 80 Days' Review: An Adventure in Self-Discovery
summary: David Tennant stars in the latest take on the famed Jules Verne novel, a PBS 'Masterpiece' presentation.. When a classic is remade, the most frequent and frequently irrelevant question concerns how much has been changed from the original. The happy answer regarding the PBS "Masterpiece" presentation of "Around the World in 80 Days": Much.

title: 'Jockey' Review: Wisdom From the Finish Line
summary: An aging jockey deals with a lifetime of physical wear and tear while showing a newcomer to horse racing his way around the track.. Doctors ask patients to describe their pain on a one-to-10 scale. I'd put the experience of watching Clint Bentley's "Jockey" close to the top, even if it's only sympathetic pain felt for the hero, Jackson Silva (Clifton Collins Jr.), a once-great rider with a battered body that can't take any more punishment after decades of routine insults, terrifying falls and grievous injuries. Yet the film also rates high on the pleasure scale for being a debut feature by abundantly gifted filmmakers and a showcase for a performance that fills your heart while frequently threatening to break it. Turns out you really can have it both ways-a harsh story with the ring of truth and a reasonably hopeful ending. (The film, written by Mr. Bentley and Greg Kwedar, is playing in theaters in New York and Los Angeles prior to expanding its distribution.)

title: Bank of Mexico Plans to Launch Digital Currency by 2024
summary: Central bank's plans aim to foster financial inclusion in a cash-based economy, government says. MEXICO CITY-The Bank of Mexico plans to put its own digital currency in circulation by 2024 to use the latest payments technology to foment financial inclusion in an economy that relies on cash for most transactions, according to the Mexican government.

title: CDC Tells Americans to Avoid Cruise Ships
summary: The health agency raised its travel warning for the vessels, advising against cruising regardless of vaccination status. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention raised its travel warning for cruise ships to its highest level, telling Americans to avoid cruises regardless of their Covid-19 vaccination status.

title: Many Hospitals Fail to Comply With Price-Disclosure Rules
summary: Some healthcare systems post incomplete pricing data or nothing at all, with no penalties yet from the Biden administration. A year after federal rules compelled hospitals to make healthcare prices public, some of the nation's biggest chains haven't done so, with no penalty so far from the Biden administration, according to a Wall Street Journal review of the $1 trillion U.S. hospital system.

title: The New Vocabulary of 2021: A Lexicon of Peeves and Passions
summary: This year, maybe you got vaxxed, explored the metaverse, joined the Great Resignation or blamed the supply chain for a no bones day.. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: The Benefits of Ethanol Are Oversold, Again
summary: It isn't 'clean,' and if it were truly the most cost-effective option, there would be no need to mandate its use.. Sen. Chuck Grassley's argument that ethanol fuel produced from corn is "clean" is a bit too clever (Letters, Dec. 23). The acreage devoted to producing corn for ethanol is about the size of the state of Ohio. Diesel fuel must be used by an army of farm equipment to plow, plant, fertilize, spray and harvest. Fertilizer comes from fossil-fuel sources and needs fossil fuels to be delivered to farmers.

title: Stop Price Discrimination Against Convenience Stores
summary: Competitors can sell sodas for less than convenience retailers can buy them wholesale.. Noah Phillips and Joshua Wright correctly note that "antitrust laws protect competition" and "competition benefits society-and consumers" ("As Inflation Rises, Antitrust 'Reformers' Target Lower Prices," op-ed, Dec. 21) But dumping the Robinson-Patman Act is the wrong conclusion. Price discrimination based on arbitrary retail "channels" raises prices and hurts competition. Even when they are larger and more efficient, convenience retailers pay higher prices than competitors on a range of products, particularly sodas.

title: The New Year's Eve Ball Will Drop, Covid or Not, if John Trowbridge Has His Way
summary: The Times Square ritual, watched by an estimated billion people, hangs on the man who manages the sphere's tech systems; will the coronavirus foil him?. The New Year's Eve Ball Drop in Times Square is a Manhattan ritual that an estimated billion people watch world-wide. Its success hangs on John Trowbridge, who manages the sphere's tech systems.

title: Conspicuous Military Failures, Russian and American
summary: Past blunders inform the situation in Ukraine.. In "It's Biden's Turn to Face Putin's Ukraine Test" (Politics & Ideas, Dec. 29), William Galston writes that Russia could defeat Ukraine quickly, but that Vladimir Putin probably doesn't want to invade. Mr. Putin's misgivings make sense, as he knows that many of Moscow's neighbors have defeated Russia in war. They include Germany (1917), Turkey (1856), Japan (1905) and newly created Poland (1918-21).

title: A Nice Cash Substitute That You Can Forget About
summary: Burton Malkiel gives away the secret.. Burton Malkiel's op-ed "The Treasury Has a Bond Bargain for You" (op-ed, Dec. 16) exposes a little-known cash substitute that I have used for years. Everyone needs some cash; how much is a different subject. Especially in times like now-low rates, expected to go higher, with bond prices falling-conventional bonds or bond funds are difficult to justify. Look to I Bonds.

title: You're Gonna Need a Bigger Battery
summary: Radical innovation is needed to put China in the rearview mirror.. Electrification of U.S. transportation requires new battery chemistries and magnet technology, both relying on materials that are earth-abundant, recyclable and readily available in North America. This is the road map to profitable sustainability, while ceding nothing to China ("The Electric-Vehicle Push Empowers China" by Robert Bryce, op-ed, Dec. 24).

title: The Flying Car Already Exists
summary: It doesn't have to be a poor airplane and a terrible car.. The U.S. Patent Office has dozens of designs for flying cars. At least one was put into production. Because of the engineering compromises required, it turned out to be a poor airplane and a terrible car ("Where Is My Flying Car?" reviewed by Philip Broughton, Bookshelf, Dec. 27).

title: Strong Labor Market in 2021 Faces Down Omicron Threat
summary: Jobless claims fell last week and are trending near a half-century low. U.S. employers added a record number of jobs in 2021, as a gauge of layoffs fell to a half-century low and available positions surged on strong demand for labor during the economy's recovery from pandemic-related shutdowns.

title: An Amazon Suit Encounters a Snag: a Judge With a Conflict of Interest
summary: Resume Subscription. For nearly two years, U.S. District Judge Liam O'Grady has handed Amazon.com Inc. a string of court victories in a continuing suit in which it accuses two former employees of taking kickbacks from a real-estate developer and violating Amazon's conflict-of-interest policies.

title: Many Climate Ambitions Will End With 2021
summary: In the U.K., Germany and France, leaders walk back as their plans' exorbitant price tag becomes clear.. It's New Year's resolution season, and don't be surprised if politicians world-wide settle into the same informal pledge: Talk as little as possible about climate change in 2022. They've gotten a head start on that resolution, working hard at it even before Friday night's socially distanced parties begin.

title: Gov. Kathy Hochul Will Tell You if You're 'Essential'
summary: If it's safe enough for a bartender to return to work after five days, it's safe enough for anybody.. Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Christmas Eve that people whose jobs New York state deems unimportant must stay home and quarantine for 10 days if they test positive for Covid-19. Others are free to return to work five days earlier. The state Health Department described its guidance as allowing for a shortened quarantine for "Healthcare Workers and Other Critical Workforce." But the meaning is the same: People will be confined to their homes not based solely on their risk of contagion but also on the government's perception of their social or economic value.

title: The Simple Soup Recipe You'll Be Making All Winter
summary: This butternut-squash soup is quick to make, full of warming spice and highly adaptable. A brown-butter streusel topping balances the silky base with a satisfying crunch.. SOUP SEASON is officially upon us. This one, chef Anne Quatrano's second Slow Food Fast recipe, combines butternut squash with a little maple syrup and heavy cream, plus warming ginger and nutmeg. The garnish is a brown-butter streusel made with toasted oats and pumpkin seeds. "I love the crunchy texture against the velvety soup," Ms. Quatrano said.

title: Ashraf Ghani Defends His Decision to Flee Afghanistan
summary: Breaking a four-month silence, former Afghan president says he regrets being too accommodating to U.S.. Afghanistan's former President Ashraf Ghani said in his first broadcast interview since fleeing Kabul that he escaped abroad because his security detail had told him that it couldn't defend him. He added that he also sought to prevent the Afghan capital from becoming a battleground between rival Taliban factions.

title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Guilty Verdict Brings 'Wave of Relief' to Epstein Accusers
summary: Women who alleged Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused them report feeling vindicated by Wednesday's verdict. The sex-trafficking conviction of British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell brings a measure of justice to the scores of women who accused disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein of sexual abuse, the accusers and their lawyers said.

title: The Models That Made Modern Science
summary: The work of constructing elaborate systems often leads to breakthroughs-even when the systems themselves turn out to be flawed. Nobel Prize-winning physicist Frank Wilczek explores the secrets of the cosmos. Read previous columns here.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended December 25
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: What Happens When You Get a Positive Covid-19 Test Traveling Overseas
summary: Extra days away from home can quickly get expensive. Here's what travelers learned and tips for making surprise stays less unpleasant.. With an increase in cases of the Omicron variant, plenty of travelers are wondering what might happen if they test positive for Covid-19 while traveling outside the U.S.

title: Converted British Water Towers Take Luxury Living to New Heights
summary: Resume Subscription. As a child, Dennis Pedersen was obsessed with sci-fi TV shows such as "The Jetsons." So when he saw the rusting hulk of a disused steel water tower perched atop a hill, surrounded by pristine English countryside, his first thought wasn't "scrap metal" but "potential."

title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un Spotlights Himself as He Marks a Decade in Power
summary: The dictator is stepping out of the shadow of his father and grandfather as Pyongyang faces deep economic woes. SEOUL-After a decade in power, Kim Jong Un has made himself clearly the star of the show in North Korea, moving beyond the legitimating familial shadow of his father and grandfather and seeking to justify his hold on power on his own terms.

title: Testing Crunch Hampers Efforts to Curb Omicron
summary: Already strapped hospitals and health departments are struggling to keep up with demand. Long lines and empty shelves continue to slow testing for Covid-19 as the highly transmissible Omicron variant spreads, with testing relief likely weeks away.

title: Sometimes Winning Means Knowing When to Quit
summary: Despite Vince Lombardi's legendary motto to the contrary, abandoning something that's not working can be the best way to succeed. Growing up in small-town Wisconsin in the 1970s, I was raised on the gritty gospel of revered Green Bay Packers coach Vince Lombardi, who famously said: "Winners never quit and quitters never win." This mind-set propelled me to an academic golf scholarship, and I was confident I would be a pro golfer. But then something unexpected happened in my freshman year: I took an honest look at my game, meticulously compared my stats with those of my peers, and realized I would never be good enough to make a living as a pro. I wondered whether I should quit on my dream.

title: Iran Sends Rocket Into Space Amid Faltering Nuclear Talks
summary: U.S. intelligence officials say Iran's space program could help advance its ballistic missiles. TEHRAN-Iran launched a rocket into space carrying what officials on Thursday said were three research devices, drawing attention to Tehran's missile ambitions amid faltering international negotiations over its nuclear program.

title: Avoiding Those Year-End Household Projects? Here Is Your Handy List of Excuses
summary: Being a homeowner is never having to say you're sorry for not cleaning the oven. The end of the year is a time of reflection, of taking stock, of tucking into bed (or smothering with a pillow) the old year and welcoming the bright shiny new year with a clean slate. Whether it's purging bad habits, bad relationships, bad clothes or a bad attitude, the new year brings the promise of promise.

title: Michigan Beat Ohio State. Is It Ready to Beat an SEC Power?
summary: Big Ten teams don't always match up to those from the SEC, but Michigan's strengths are uniquely matched to Georgia's in the Orange Bowl. Michigan's football team isn't glamorous. Its passing game is more methodical than explosive. Its running game is a steady grind. The Wolverines' flashiest component may be its wrecking-ball defensive end Aidan Hutchinson, who became the rare Heisman Trophy finalist who isn't a quarterback or wide receiver.

title: Manulife's Jeff Hammer Sees Secondary Market Boom Driving More Mergers in 2022
summary: The global co-head of private-market secondaries at Manulife Investment Management said the secondary market's success drove a surprising amount of merger activity in 2021 with more likely to come next year.

title: Biden Aims to Cut Approval Times for New Power Lines
summary: The administration wants to increase federal involvement in building high-voltage lines, which often takes years, to boost renewable energy growth. The Biden administration is trying to speed up the permitting process for high-voltage power lines as part of its drive to promote renewable energy.

title: BTS's NFT Venture Hits Sour Note With Fans
summary: Supporters criticize energy consumption needed for nonfungible tokens, but management says NFT plans will still move forward. SEOUL-When BTS unveiled plans last month to break into the NFT business, the South Korean boy band's supporters revolted online, threatening boycotts and lodging environmental concerns.

summary: The best visual stories of the year from The Wall Street Journal. Copyright ©2022 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8

title: Credit-Risk Return Doesn't Have to Be Unwanted Sequel
summary: Delinquencies and charge-offs of some consumer loans will likely rise in 2022, but banks are in a position to handle a steady increase. Consumer credit risk was in retreat in 2021. It might begin to return next year, though not necessarily in a way that should worry bank investors yet.

title: Investors Pile Into Supply-Chain Technology
summary: A flood of big money is pumping up valuations of logistics startups as global bottlenecks raise the profile of a once-overlooked sector. An investment rush into logistics technology is creating a herd of unicorns in the race to digitize operations at the center of the world's supply-chain gridlock.

title: Some Companies Are Ready for Libor's Demise, but Not All
summary: U.S. banks won't be allowed to issue new debt tied to the benchmark in 2022, leaving some firms struggling to decide how to proceed. Wall Street's shift away from the London interbank offered rate takes effect at the start of the new year. Some companies are more prepared for it than others.

title: Michigan's Citizen-Led Redistricting Draws Hope for Fairer Process
summary: Advocates for change in how elections are conducted are watching what is happening in the state. Legal challenges are mounting in some states, as the redrawing of congressional districts proceeds across the U.S., potentially reshaping the balance of power in state capitals and Washington, D.C.

title: What a Science Teacher Taught the Dallas Cowboys About Coaching
summary: The Cowboys wanted to be better prepared if Covid-19 forced them to conduct meetings virtually again. They brought in Zoom coaches from a nearby college.. After the 2020 NFL season ended, Dallas Cowboys coach Mike McCarthy introduced his staff to a pair of experts he hoped would make them better at coaching football. Coordinators sat in the front row and took detailed notes. They peppered their lecturers with questions. They learned so much that it would transform the way they do their jobs.

title: Suspect in Japan Fire That Killed 25 Dies From Injuries
summary: The blaze targeted a mental-health facility in central Osaka. TOKYO-The man suspected of starting a fire that killed 25 people at a Japanese mental-health clinic earlier this month has died of injuries from the incident, police said.

title: Top Chinese Quant Fund Apologizes to Investors After Recent Struggles
summary: High-Flyer Quant uses artificial-intelligence technology to pick domestic yuan-denominated stocks. One of China's largest managers of quant funds is languishing after a rare bout of underperformance in recent months, which led to an unusual public apology from the company this week.

title: A Bad Year for Hydrogen Stocks Was Good for Hydrogen Companies
summary: The sector's growth prospects are more sensibly valued after a year of deflating stock prices and industrial progress. After a gravity-defying 2020, hydrogen stocks have drifted back toward Earth this year. Investor expectations are now better pitched for a sector offering huge growth prospects but on a still-uncertain, subsidy-dependent time scale.

title: Big Tech's $10 Trillion Bet on Politics as Usual
summary: Soaring market values reflect growing belief that regulations won't trip Apple, Google, Facebook or Amazon. The wisdom of crowds doesn't always prevail. But more than $10 trillion has been wagered that it will in the coming year.

title: Omicron Roils Australia's Exit From Zero-Covid Strategy
summary: Australia's struggles could presage similar challenges in Asian countries that have tried to eliminate the virus or keep cases low. ADELAIDE, Australia-Australia's shift to living with Covid-19 after keeping cases near zero for much of the pandemic was based on a bet that a high vaccination rate would limit severe illness and hospitalizations.

title: Desktop PC Sales Rebound as Pandemic Work Evolves
summary: Computing performance, screen size and price have proved to be the machine's enduring benefits. The desktop computer is making a comeback.

title: U.S. Sanctions Push Afghanistan and Iran Together
summary: Resume Subscription. ZARANJ, Afghanistan-Two decades ago, Iran helped the U.S. topple the Taliban regime to remove what it saw as a threat to its national security and fellow Shia Muslims in Afghanistan.

title: Covid-19 Rapid Test Shortages Tied to Slow Federal Action
summary: Long authorization process is part of nationwide failure to make and distribute enough of the tests, public-health experts say. As rising Covid-19 infections stoked demand for tests across the U.S. in December, California-based LumiQuick Diagnostics Inc. shipped 100,000 rapid tests to a hospital customer-in Germany.

title: Foggy Regulations Challenge Crypto, Gemini Compliance Chief Says
summary: Elena Hughes joined cryptocurrency exchange Gemini in 2020 after more than a decade in traditional financial institutions. Opaque regulations remain a top challenge for the cryptocurrency industry, according to Elena Hughes, chief compliance officer of cryptocurrency exchange Gemini Trust Co.

title: How Tesla Navigated the Chip Shortage
summary: Electric-vehicle maker is expected to manufacture roughly 80% more vehicles this year than it did in 2020. Tesla Inc. has emerged as one of the auto industry's biggest winners in a year plagued by semiconductor shortages and snarled global supply chains. It owes that success in some measure to its Silicon Valley roots.

title: As Chinese IPOs Stumble, Investors Look Elsewhere in Asia
summary: India, South Korea and Southeast Asia have become sources of alluring, big-ticket initial public offerings. For investors looking to bet on new share offerings in Asia, the center of gravity is shifting away from China.

title: Americans Diverge on Views of the Jan. 6 Capitol Attack
summary: A year after the riot by Trump supporters, Democrats see the events as an attack on the government, while many Republicans disagree. WASHINGTON-Nearly a year after the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol by Trump supporters, Americans are divided over how serious it was, who is to blame and the punishments that have been imposed, underscoring the broader polarization facing the country and fanning concerns about the state of the democracy.

title: Budgeting for 2022 Is Easier With These Tips
summary: Inflation and other factors likely mean you'll spend more in 2022. Here's why that's OK.. Here's a prescription for money happiness in 2022: Accept the fact that you'll likely spend more money than you did in 2021.

title: SenseTime Shares Jump in Hong Kong Market Debut
summary: U.S. government had added SenseTime to an investment blacklist that barred Americans from buying shares in the firm. HONG KONG-Shares of SenseTime Group Inc. jumped in their Hong Kong market debut, after the Chinese artificial-intelligence leader completed a $744 million initial public offering that had been delayed by tensions between Washington and Beijing.

title: Didi Stock Remains Mired in the Twilight Zone
summary: Losing several billion dollars is just the tip of the iceberg for the beleaguered Chinese ride-hailing giant. Didi investors have finally gotten a clear glimpse into its financials following the Chinese ride-hailing giant's fateful run-in with Beijing. It isn't a pretty picture.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
